document_title: Eclampsia: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
Eclampsia (Eclampsia in English) is a complication of severe preeclampsia, at which time pregnant women experience severe seizures or deep coma of unknown cause. Seizures can occur before birth, at 20 weeks of pregnancy, during birth or after birth, especially in pregnant women who have had signs and symptoms of preeclampsia.
Eclampsia often follows preeclampsia, characterized by elevated blood pressure that occurs during pregnancy and after birth. However, postpartum cases are more rare. When the pregnant woman's condition becomes severe, affecting the brain leading to seizures, the pregnant woman has eclampsia.
